desc: show that sum of 8 numbers exactly one from each row and column is always 260
solution:
\begin{soln}
  Number the rows and columns from $1$ to $8$ from left to right
  top to bottom respectively.

  Let $a_{i,j}$ denote the cell of ith row and jth
  column.

  Note that $a_{i,j}=8(i-1)+j$. Now,
  \[
  a_{i,j}+a_{m,n}=a_{m,j}+a_{i,n}=a_{i,n}+a_{j,m}
  .\]
  
  So we can swap the indices of the rows and columns when the
  two $a_{i,j}$ are in sum.

  Let $\left\{ a_{i_{1},j_1},a_{i_2,j_2},\dots,
  a_{i_8,j_8} \right\}$ 
  be the chosen cells.

  Therefore, $\left\{ i_1,i_2,\dots,i_8 \right\}$ and
  $\left\{ j_1,j_2,\dots,j_8 \right\}$ are a
  permutation of $\left\{ 1,2,\dots,8 \right\}$ since one cell
  is chosen from each row and column.

  We can permute the $\left\{ i_1,i_2,\dots,i_8 \right\}$ in
  a pairwise manner such that they change to $1$, $2$, \dots, 8
 in order and the sum of $\sum_{k=1}^n a_{i_k,j_k}$
  remains the same. Similarly we can permute the indices of the
  columns too.

  Therefore,
  \[
      \sum_{n=1}^{8} a_{i_n,j_n}=\sum_{n=1}^{8} a_{n,n}
    = \sum_{n=1}^{8} 8(k-1)+k
    = 260
  .\qedhere\]
\end{soln}
